item.title: inventory cogs nrv fai0003as
item.description: Remember: The Net Realizable Value (NRV) of the inventory is the value for which the inventory can be sold. If the inventory cannot be sold for an amount higher than its cost (i.e., the NRV is lower than the cost of inventory) then the inventory should be reported at the NRV amount instead of its cost. To record the decrease in the value of the inventory to its NRV the following journal entry is made: increase the cost of goods sold and decrease the inventory.

item.title: ppe cost model fapi0002br
item.description: Remember: The cost of any asset is the sum of all the costs incurred to bring the asset to its intended use. Question: Company A paid $9,008 cash for equipment used in the business. At the time of purchase the equipment had a list price of $19,165. When the balance sheet was prepared, the market value of the equipment was $21,310. Which of the three amounts is the most relevant amount that should be used for measurement subsequent to initial recognition under the cost model?

item.title: intangibles goodwill fapi0001aapaapae
item.description: Remember: Goodwill = Purchase Price - Fair value of identifiable net assets (of seller) Goodwill is an intangible asset with indefinite live that can be impaired. Anheuser-Busch InBev reached an agreement in 2016 to buy SABMiller for a purchase price of $100 billion, making for the biggest beer acquisition on record and one of the largest in corporate history. The fair value of the net identifiable assets of SABMiller before the acquisition was $98 billion.

item.title: ending inventory fai0002aap
item.description: Remember: Beginning inventory + Purchases - Cost of Goods Sold = Ending inventory Beginning inventory of 2015 = Ending inventory of 2014 Question: The ending inventory for the year ended December 31, 2014, is understated. How will this erros affect the net income for 2014 and 2015? 2014 overstated; 2015 understated 2014 overstated; 2015 no effect 2014 overstated; 2015 no effect 2014 understated; 2015 overstated Solution: Point 4.

item.title: depreciation gain cash fafs0001es
item.description: Remember: Cash from the sale of property, plant and equipment is equal to the value of the asset (net of amortization or depreciation) plus/minus the gain/loss. In the indirect method the expenses (e.g., depreciation expense) or gains that do not involve cash are added to the net profit to find the cash from operating activities. Cash flow from investing activities relates to the purchase and sale of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets.
